title: 112_hr198
content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" may be cited as the short title. The Department of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program on dog training therapy. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using training service dogs to address post-deployment mental health and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms in veterans with disabilities. The program will run for five years at three to five VA medical centers. The pilot program will be conducted at three to five VA medical centers over a five-year period. The selected centers must have a dedicated space for grooming and training service dogs indoors. The pilot program requires VA medical centers to provide training areas for educating veterans with mental health conditions in service dog training. Training areas must include indoor space for grooming and training dogs, wheelchair accessibility, classroom space, office space, equipment storage, and access to other training areas for specialized training. The pilot program mandates VA medical centers to have indoor training areas for educating veterans with mental health conditions in service dog training. These areas must be wheelchair accessible, have classroom and office space, equipment storage, outdoor exercise space for dogs, and provide transportation for field trips. The Secretary is responsible for designing the pilot program. The pilot program requires VA medical centers to have indoor training areas for educating veterans with mental health conditions in service dog training. The program includes training dogs with wheelchairs, outdoor exercise space, and transportation for field trips. The Secretary is responsible for overseeing the program through the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary will administer the pilot program through the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs. A certified recreational therapist will oversee all pilot program sites. A director of service dog training will be established for overseeing the training of dogs at selected medical centers, with specific qualifications required. The pilot program will have a director of service dog training overseeing the training of dogs at medical centers. Certified service dog training instructors will be at each pilot program site. Dogs from shelters or foster homes may be considered for the program. The pilot program for individuals with post-traumatic stress disorder will have certified service dog training instructors at each site. Dogs from shelters or foster homes may be used if appropriate, with a focus on temperament and health clearances. Service dogs in training will be taught essential commands and will live at the program site. The pilot program ensures that service dogs have proper temperament and health clearances, are taught essential commands, live at the program site or a volunteer foster home, receive hands-on training, and follow a structured training program. The pilot program involves training service dogs in lecture and hands-on sessions to benefit veterans with disabilities, specifically those with post-traumatic stress disorder or other post-deployment mental health conditions. The pilot program aims to maximize therapeutic benefits for veterans with disabilities by providing well-trained service dogs. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other post-deployment mental health conditions can participate if resources are available. Veterans can also join the program alongside the compensated work therapy program of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The pilot program offers veterans with disabilities the opportunity to participate in service dog training. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other mental health conditions can join if resources are available. Preference is given to veterans who have graduated from residential treatment programs and have certification in service dog training when hiring instructors. The Secretary gives preference to veterans with certification in service dog training and who have graduated from residential treatment programs when hiring service dog training instructors. Data collection is required to assess the effectiveness of the pilot program in assisting veterans with reducing stigma associated with post-traumatic stress. The Secretary will collect data on the pilot program to determine its effectiveness for veterans, including reducing stigma, improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, helping fellow veterans, and community reintegration. The pilot program aims to help veterans by improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, community reintegration, relationship skills, sleep patterns, and reducing the use of pain medication. The pilot program aims to help veterans by reducing social isolation, building relationship skills, relaxing hyper-vigilance, improving sleep patterns, and decreasing pain medication use. Reports to Congress on the program's progress are required annually. The Secretary must report annually to Congress on the pilot program's progress, including the number of participating veterans, services provided, and the effects on symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder and post-deployment adjustment difficulties. The Secretary must report annually to Congress on the pilot program's progress, including services provided and effects on symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, family dynamics, insomnia, and pain management. The Secretary's annual report to Congress on the pilot program includes information on depression, sobriety maintenance, suicidal ideations, homelessness, physiological markers related to service dog interactions, family dynamics, insomnia, pain management, and overall well-being, along with recommendations for program extension or expansion. The term "service dog training instructor" is defined as an instructor providing training services. The term "service dog training instructor" refers to an instructor who trains veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder and other post-deployment issues in service dog training. The pilot program's annual report includes information on depression, sobriety maintenance, suicidal ideations, homelessness, physiological markers related to service dog interactions, family dynamics, insomnia, pain management, overall well-being, and recommendations for program extension or expansion.
